Posts.Title: protocol on scans??? nobleanna007 nobleanna007

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 12:22PM - edited Jun 4, 2008 12:24PM by Westie HKitty, I drove as soon as my drains were out (7 days later). Keryl, a drain is a clear plastic tube sewn in 6 inches or so  beside the incision (under your upper arm, on your body).  The tube is anout 30 inches long with a plastic bulb(about the size of a grenade) at the end which collects fluid which would otherwise have to be absorbed by the body.  The bulb has to be emptied a few times a day at first, then less and less until the drain may be removed.  It doesn't hurt (trust me) and helps you heal faster.  I had a home care nurse once a day to check mine and remove them when it was time.
Posts.Title: How long will I need FT help at home after surgery? BustersMom Nice_Nichols

Posts.Content: Jun 25, 2008 10:37AM Westie wrote: Call your doc to be on the safe side, but I can tell you I had the exact same sensations as you are.  The crawly ones I found especially creepy.  It all went away.  3 months out, I still have numbness in my upper arm.  I think this is permanent, but the main thing is I have full mobility. Take your pain meds(of course).  Sending hugs!

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2009 10:40AM Westie wrote: OK, I am a a smoker and we all know how stupid it is. At my pre-op my bp was 100/68, pulse 72, and Oxygen saturation 98%.  The pre-op nurse said 'well you can just keep on smoking right up to your surgery.'  I was up and about after 2 days and I healed very quickly.  My scar is flat and white.

Posts.Title: Loss of Appetite Jo_Ann_K Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2008 11:55PM Westie wrote: Hi, You will get through this.  The surgery is not really taxing because they're not cutting you open, they're removing things from the outside.  I had surgery, 4months of chemo and am on my 18th of 30 radiations.  I found it helpful not to pile everything on myself and get through one day at a time.  So far, it has worked. I wish you were here, we could have a nice cup of tea and discuss. Also, don't be shy about asking your Dr. for anti-anxiety medication.  It calms you down and helps you sleep. You will do it all, one thing at a time.  Keep us posted.
